Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Aging Propagation and Model-Based Prognosis for Interconnected Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objectives of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award are to develop a methodology to understand the propagation of aging in engineered system consisting of many interconnects subsystem and components, and to demonstrate it by developing tools and methods to predict life and understand the state of health of battery pack systems in plug-in hybrid electric vehicles. The first goal of the research is to understand how knowledge of the aging behavior of individual components (e.g.: battery cells) translates into overall system aging. The second goal is to develop a systematic approach to assess the state of health of the system based on knowledge of its components states of health. The resulting approaches are then demonstrated using a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle battery pack as a case study, in collaboration with General Motors. Deliverables include: mathematical models and computer simulations of aging propagation in a battery pack; the experimental validation of the life prediction methods, in collaboration with General Motors; graduate course materials; and a short course designed for industrial audiences.


The outcome of this work will have a broad impact on the theory, methodology and application of failure prognosis to engineered systems, beyond the specific application considered in this project. The participation of General Motors in this project is critical in that it provides an opportunity to validate and implement the methodology in a real-world setting that presents many important challenges such as cost constraints, the application to a large number of systems (potentially millions of vehicles), and the need to achieve a degree of robustness that is consistent with today's consumer expectations of warranty. If this research on aging propagation and prognosis for interconnected systems is successful, it will greatly help in making informed and timely life cycle management decisions, reducing warranty and maintenance costs while improving serviceability, availability and safety.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The supervision of complex engineering systems and processes requires the presence of a variety of diagnostic and prognostic functions to insure three important system properties: 1) availability– that is the ability to retain critical system functionality at all times; 2) safety– that is the guarantee that under faulty conditions the system will continue to operate in a safe manner, or in compliance with existing regulations; and 3) serviceability, that is the assurance that the system can be rapidly serviced or re-configured in the event of one or more malfunctions; this latter property can be of critical importance in the cost-effective operation of a complex network of systems, whether interconnected or individually operated. The three properties are intimately connected to the subject of system prognosis.

Real world systems are inherently subject to aging. Aging is the reduction in performance, availability, reliability, and life span of a system or component. The generation of long-term predictions describing the evolution of the aging in time for the purpose of predicting the Remaining Useful Life (RUL) of a system may be understood as Prognosis. Prognosis is one of the key enablers for Prognostics and Heath Management (PHM). PHM aims to help in making informed and timely life cycle management decisions, reducing warranty and maintenance costs while improving serviceability, availability and safety. Life cycle management decisions include:

1) scheduling maintenance, including: minimizing unscheduled maintenance, extending maintainance cycles, and maintaining effectiveness through timely repair actions;

2) end-of-life decision making helping to determine whether product life can be extended, whether any component can be reused, and what subsystems should be disposed off to minimize system costs; and

3) Aging mitigation or life-extending management.

Most of the state-of-the-art research is focused on the RUL prediction for single components. This project considers prognosis of complex interconnected systems in which aging of one component propagates to other components depending on the connectivity.

During this project fundamental new understanding of aging propagation between the components of interconnected engineered system is established. This fundamental knowledge is used to –

1)     develop a multi-physics model of a battery pack in a Plug in Hybrid Electric Vehicle (PHEV) including its aging phenomena

2)     develop a prognosis algorithm which can predict the probability of a pack reaching certain level of system health in certain time, and probability of single cells to be the most aged

This information is important for effective PHM. The algorithm developed in the project is capable of considering manufacturing tolerances in the cells, uncertainties due to unknown future operating conditions and uncertainties in the aging model calibrations. Although, a specific example of PHEV battery pack is considered, the usefulness can be realized in a vast majority of industries, for example – aviation, renewable energy generation and storage, military, medical equipment, off-highway vehicles, robotics etc.

 

This project, a GOALI collaboration between the PIs at The Ohio State University (OSU) and General Motors Corporation (GM), has resulted into two major contributions: 1) a formal understanding of aging propagation in a complex interconnected systems that allow for model-based prognosis of system health; 2) development of an RUL prediction algorithm which could be implemented in a production grade vehicle.

Further, this project has had significant training and educational impact. Three PhD students were trained through this project, out of which one was a female Hispanic. The PI of this project has included topics on prognosis in a graduate level curriculum at the OSU. Also, a short course on battery pack aging modeling, and control has been developed which may be made available on request to the PI.
